So essentially, in 2012, I started a consulting practice answering the specific question, ‘What ERP is Best for My Business’ and work full time getting the right consultants to the client organization to study, uncover, discover, probe, and learn every little thing about the business - and then and only then, we make some recommendations and invite the software vendors to ‘prove’ our recommendations. We end up working in some fashion (either long or short engagements, depending) with about 15 companies a year. We’ve helped implement Netsuite twice and Intacct twice, but all the others have been different systems, Oracle, SAP, Syteline, Unit4, Microsoft Dynamics AX, NAV, GP, Sage X3, Epicor, Lawson, and so on, because those systems were best for those clients. So for some companies, we spend a couple of weeks and it’s pretty obvious what is likely the fit. Some complex companies take longer. But it’s true, there is no single best ERP software for all businesses, there is however, the best solution for a particular business.

The primary goal of ERP software is to make used business processes more efficient. ERP software allows automating the large part of the workflow by collecting orders, generating and delivering reports on these orders, gathering, sorting, and storing data that helps to make each company department more efficient. As a result, company employees get the ability to cut out a significant number of tasks and minimize the amount of work each manager has to complete.
